title: You’ve got to try these 7 3D printing projects to improve your skills
description: These 3D printing projects can help improve your skills.
author: Jeff Butts
excerpt: If you want to elevate your 3D printing skills, give one of these projects a whirl
text: 3D printing is a fantastic way to learn and get creative, no matter how experienced you are. Whether you’re just starting or a seasoned pro, each project you create will give you a new perspective. These projects help you build confidence in troubleshooting and experimenting. Plus, they’re a great way to learn about design principles like stability, accuracy, and finishing techniques. You’ll also see how print settings like layer height and fill density affect the final product. Related 5 things I wish someone told me before I started 3D printing Get to know of these five issues I wish I knew before starting 3D printing to help save you time, material, and money along the way. 7 Design a custom smartphone stand Practice precision while creating a practical everyday accessory This project focuses on balancing structural considerations and aesthetic choices. You can customize angles, material thickness, and decorative elements to reflect your style while maintaining functionality. During the modeling phase, practice fine-tuning measurements, so your phone rests securely without slipping. Experiment with small details, such as slots for charging cables, to make your final stand more convenient. Strength and stability are key factors to consider during the design process. If you plan to print with materials like PLA, check that the base and sides are sturdy enough to hold a heavier device. Consider test-printing scaled versions or partial sections for an early look at fit and finish. These steps save time and resources before committing to the final model. You can accent your stand with a range of post-processing options. Simple sanding and priming techniques often improve the look of the finished print. Adding paint or decals can transform an otherwise basic frame into a visually pleasing display. These extra touches make your project even more rewarding as a learning experience and a personalized desk accessory. 6 Craft your own cable management system Bring order to tangled cables with simple printed solutions Creating custom cable management for your workspace helps you learn about small-scale design. Each clip must fit snugly around cables, so accurate measurements and tight tolerances matter. Examine which cable sizes you use the most, and ensure your design accommodates them comfortably. This approach keeps your final prints both practical and visually consistent. Test different clip styles, such as those that attach with adhesive or slide onto the edge of a surface. You might discover that one shape or orientation best suits your specific environment. If your desk is cluttered, print a few prototypes to see which clip arrangement effectively addresses your cable tangles. Pay attention to how the orientation of each clip affects printing time and material usage. Adjusting clip shapes allows you to manage cables and wires for headphones or chargers. Rolling out incremental improvements on small designs like these strengthens your ability to tweak details in modeling software. Over time, you will see how slight variations in wall thickness or hole diameter impact the clip’s strength and grip. Fine-tuning these factors contributes to a tidy, more efficient setup. 5 Print a functional water bottle holder Experiment with structural design for stable daily hydration needs A sturdy water bottle holder can be helpful in cars, bicycles, or workspaces. To ensure a reliable fit, you can practice aligning form and function by designing your own. Begin by measuring your preferred bottle’s diameter and height, adding a small margin for easy insertion. These steps help you avoid loose prints or overly tight designs. When deciding how thick or reinforced each segment should be, focus on structural integrity. Pay attention to areas prone to stress, such as points of contact with the bottle or mounting bolts. Use infill settings that match the holder’s intended purpose; a higher infill percentage might be useful for a part that experiences frequent movement. This approach ensures that your final product can withstand daily use. You can also explore alternative designs to hold thermoses or insulated bottles. Varying shapes and grips can accommodate different beverage containers. Experiment with new angles or support brackets to adapt the holder for backpacks, gym bags, or bicycle frames. You gain confidence in designing parts that handle specific tasks through these variations. 4 Make a personalized desk nameplate Refine intricate lettering techniques for personalized professional settings Nameplates are excellent for practicing precision in text design and post-processing. You can adjust font styles, letter spacing, and embellishments to suit your personal or professional environment. Begin by drafting your nameplate in 3D modeling software, keeping the letters connected with a stable backing. This prevents delicate pieces from shifting or breaking during printing. The thickness of each letter plays a role in how cleanly they print. If the letters are too thin, they may cause warping or gaps during extrusion. Meanwhile, a well-chosen layer height can highlight every subtle detail in your lettering. By experimenting with different print speeds and temperatures, you can reduce the chance of stringing or blurry edges. Once your nameplate is printed, explore surface smoothing techniques like gentle sanding or applying a light coat of primer. These steps can help your letters pop, especially when you add a final layer of paint or metallic accents. For an added challenge, experiment with inlaying contrasting filament colors. This approach makes your design look more polished and reflects your ability to handle detailed work. 3 Build an adjustable tablet stand Incorporate pivot elements for comfortable and flexible viewing options An adjustable stand brings another layer of complexity to 3D-printed designs. You learn to include moving parts, such as pivot points or hinges, that let the tablet rest at various angles. Selecting durable joint designs is essential because they must handle repeated movement without cracking. Consider tolerances and friction points during the modeling stage to ensure a smooth, stable tilt mechanism. To avoid printing multiple unnecessary prototypes, use small test prints for each pivot. This allows you to fine-tune joint dimensions before committing to the full stand. If you plan to use larger tablets, consider reinforcing any sections that support extra weight. Small washers or hardware can also improve hinge functionality, helping the stand maintain its position without slipping. Experiment with different hinge styles, such as ball-and-socket or folding joints. You can also integrate cable management slots or hooks to keep chargers neatly routed. These design touches elevate a simple stand into a versatile workstation accessory. With every adjustment, you learn how 3D printing can meet your everyday needs. Enhance efficiency by designing stable and portable compartments A well-designed tool caddy gives you hands-on practice structuring multiple compartments while focusing on overall stability. You can tailor each section to fit items such as pliers, screwdrivers, or 3D printer accessories that you use frequently. During the modeling process, consider how to balance wall thickness and material usage, so your caddy remains sturdy yet lightweight. This will encourage you to refine your print settings for dimensional accuracy. Consider adding a handle or carrying slot to make your caddy more mobile. By experimenting with different handle shapes, you can find a comfortable grip that complements the caddy’s overall look. Test small variations in curvature or thickness to see how each tweak affects the final design. As you refine these details, you will become more confident in your ability to customize everyday storage solutions. Post-processing can be as simple or creative as you like. Sanding or priming the surface helps remove layer lines and prepares it for paint, giving your caddy a smooth finish. You can also print labels or incorporate embossed icons for specific tools, adding a polished touch. These personalized elements make your caddy a reflection of your evolving design skills. 1 Experiment with mechanical gears for creative displays Integrate moving components for artistic and interactive designs Designing gear mechanisms offers a fun challenge that blends aesthetics with functional engineering. Start with basic gear shapes to understand how their teeth interlock and transfer motion. Adjust the tooth profile or gear ratio with each prototype to fine-tune movement and reduce friction. This process encourages you to experiment with print orientation and small tolerances to ensure gears mesh smoothly. Once you grasp the fundamentals, you can incorporate decorative elements such as patterns or unique spokes. These flourishes add visual interest, making your gear assembly more than just a technical exercise. If you want a more interactive project, combine multiple gear sets or use a simple crank to engage viewers. This approach transforms your creation into a kinetic sculpture that showcases your growing expertise. Testing different materials, like PETG or ABS, broadens your understanding of how gear mechanisms behave under stress. You might discover that a specific filament type reduces binding or handles repeated motion more reliably. By methodically iterating these designs, you refine your problem-solving skills. This experience can be applied to more ambitious projects that rely on smoothly interacting parts. Discover new frontiers to elevate your printing expertise New projects are a great way to practice modeling and problem-solving, nurturing a deeper understanding of this technology. As you refine your techniques, tackle more ambitious creations that help you explore innovative ideas. Doing so broadens your appreciation of how design theory and real-world performance work together. With every successful print, you build confidence and uncover fresh possibilities that spark your imagination.
